media.caption: Figure 14. A) Inferred paleoglaciological setting of the field trip area at time of the last glacial maximum.  B) Converging ice streams (SIS: Simcoe Ice Stream and HIS: Halton Ice Stream) during the final retreat of the Laurentide Ice Sheet sometime shortly before 13,000 ybp. The Oak Ridges Moraine was deposited in a narrow glaciolacustrine depocentre trapped between the two ice streams and dammed to the west by the Niagara Escarpment (Fig. 26).

Figure 15. Simplified distribution of hard and soft beds below principal ice streams in Southern Ontario. Inset boxes A, B, and C are the locations of the glacially streamlined bedrock surfaces shown in Figures 18, 20, and 21, respectively. The hard bed is offset by numerous faults (Fig. 17). Insets D and E are locations of Figures 22 and 26, which show typical streamlined soft beds with megascale glacial lineations. Note the large expanse of the so-called Dummer Moraine, which is composed of limestone rubble plucked from north-facing escarpments.
